top_categories.workout_context: 250 miles. Your legs will beg to quit after 120. This trains the power output you need from mile 130 onward.
250 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.
Tour de Nebraska's mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 250 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Tour de Nebraska's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before June.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 250 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 3,500ft of climbing on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel does to your power file on race day.
Tour de Nebraska's mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
At Tour de Nebraska, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Tempo is Tour de Nebraska's race pace. The wattage you'll hold for 250 miles on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel. Train it until it's automatic.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Tour de Nebraska. Train it until it feels boring.
When someone attacks on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Tour de Nebraska, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.

race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 250 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 250 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Tour de Nebraska requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) to build confidence.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, HVLI Extended, and Gravel Specific to prepare you for 250 miles of mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) in Southwest Nebraska (Curtis, Elwood, Cambridge, McCook).
